Initial results from running with crossover working as you described
look w=
orse than with the old way; however, I think that the mutation
rates need t=
o be tweaked because now mutations in individuals quickly
spread throughout=
 the species.

I'm going to try to play with the mutation rates and see if =
I can get
it to work better, but I think it might actually work better with=
out
performing crossover on each gene.

I'll let you know what I find out.
=

Jason G.

ect: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
> > 
> > T=
he question about crossover in NEAT is interesting.  Although it does
> > n=
ot provide a huge boost in performance, it is still a significant
> > advan=
ce compared to what came before in neuroevolution, which is why
> > it is s=
till a payoff.  The competing conventions problem (also called
> > the "top=
ology matching problem") was a huge issue in neuroevolution
> > before NEAT=
, and because of it some researchers were questioning
> > whether there was=
 any hope for crossover at all in such systems.  It
> > could be shown in p=
rior systems without historical marking that
> > crossover actually hurts t=
he evolution of neural networks, making its
> > prospects dim.  Angeline an=
d Pollack even introduced a neuroevolution
> > method called GNARL (before =
NEAT) that didn't even have crossover as
> > an operator because of the con=
cern.  In this context, NEAT made
> > crossover safe for neuroevolution and=
 removed its stigma in such
> > systems.  That is, it switched it from a li=
ability to an advantage
> > that boosts performance a bit in NEAT.  So it's=
 an advance in that
sense.
> > 
> > However, while the "bit" of performance=
 gain (vs. having no crossover)
> > *is* likely statistically significant, =
it is not huge.  The real
> > benefit of historical markings
> > is that it=
 enables speciation, which does have a dramatic effect
> > because of prote=
cting innovation to support complexification.
> > Crossover is more like ic=
ing on the cake.  However, I think many
> > people identify NEAT with cross=
over because it is such a clear
> > demonstration of the benefit of histori=
cal markings.  In that sense,
> > it is perhaps conceptually more significa=
nt than it is functionally.
> > Still, I would recommend keeping it if you =
can, since it does appear
> > to be better to have it than not, albeit not =
enormously.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <=
jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Thanks Ken. I was guessing the same thing based =
on (1). I can't
> > think of any
> >> good reason at the moment why crossov=
er would help/hurt HyperNEAT
> > more than
> >> P-NEAT. 
> >> 
> >> (2) sur=
prises me, however. Isn't one of the hallmarks of NEAT the
> >> intelligent=
 crossover via historical markings? I guess I just
> > assumed that
> >> ha=
d been shown to provide a huge payoff. If crossover doesn't help
> > that m=
uch
> >> in NEAT, how much does *intelligent* (vs. na=EF=BF=BDve) crossover=
 help?
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune

 >>>>> Yeah, it looks like you hit the nail on the head.  Right now, it

s to be. Note that
> >>> randomChoice has
> >>>>>>> to be random every time=
 you refer to it. If it is not random
(i.e.
> >>>>>>> outside the big loop)=
 then you choose links from either parent.
> >>> But if
> >>>>>>> it is ins=
ide the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from
either
> >>>>>>> parent.=
 Check this out and you will have a clearer picture if
> >>> there is
> >>>=
>>>> a bug or not.
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> Thanks Petar. I am confident that Hyp=
erNEAT 2.5 chooses the
parent
> >>>>> outside
> >>>>>> the loop, and thus g=
rabs all links from either parent1 or
parent2.
> >>>>> What I am
> >>>>>> t=
rying to find out is whether this is by design, or if it is
a bug.
> >>>>>>=

T
> >>>>> packages,
> >>>>>> in particular Ken's original NEAT code? My gue=
ss is that we are
> >>>>> supposed to
> >>>>>> be grabbing some links from =
parent1 and some other links from
> >>> parent2,
> >>>>>> instead of one or=
 the other. I can go check those packages, of
> >>>>> course, but I
> >>>>>=
> won't be able to do that for a little while and was wondering
> > if any
=
> >>>>> of you
> >>>>>> knew off the top of your heads.
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>=
 But the cloning issue is a deeper one. In this case you must
> > ensure
> =
>>>>>>> that individuals should not mate with themselves or such
ones that
=
> >>>>>>> have zero compatibility distance. Or at least try a few hundred
>=
 >>> times
> >>>>>>> to find a different mate :) Hey, I say this to all use=
rs.

> >>>>>>> rand(), fuck that, use the Mersenne Twister ins=
tead. I noticed
> >>> that in
> >>>>>>> enhances performance!
> >>>>>>

>>>>> Fair enough, but right now I am more focused on the more

ate issue

into them

 Thanks. Jeff.

ng line occurs outside of the loop that goes through

ink:

(randomChoice<=3Dpa=
rent1->getFitness());

h link:

>=
 >>>>>>>>                     {

GeneticLinkGene(*link1));

               else

             addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));

   }

> >>>>>>>>> Hi Jeff, 
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> Well I don't know about the=
 exact implementations of
> > HyperNEAT you
> >>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>> using=
 (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations
> >>>>>>>>> disable=
d), but in principle crossover should choose genes
> > randomly
> >>>>>>>>>=
 from both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the
> > child. In
> >=
>>>>>>>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a
> >>=
>>>>> regular
> >>>>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other netwo=
rks based
> > on the
> >>>>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you only=
 mate and mutate the
> >>>>>>> CPPNs.
> >>>>>>>>> But in the case you get l=
ots of individuals with equal
> > fitness, I
> >>>>>>>>> guess these indivi=
duals are clones. Perhaps the code
frequently
> >>>>>>>>> chooses the same =
individuals for mating? You can try to
> > avoid this
> >>>>>>> by
> >>>>>>=
>>> introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a
> > "father" that
=
> >>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>> not compatible with the mother, that is, when the=
ir
> > compatibility
> >>>>>>>>> distance is 0.00, try again. There is anot=
her possibility,
> > simply
> >>>>>>>>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN an=
d therefore the produced
> >>>>>>> network is
> >>>>>>>>> changed in such a=
 magnitude that is has no chance for
> > survival and
> >>>>>>> is
> >>>>>>=
>>> discarded. Even though there is speciation.
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> Pe=
ter
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff=
 Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Hello all-
> >>>>>>>>>> =

> >>>>>>>>>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >>>>>>>>=
>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> PNEAT:
> >>>>>>>>>> If I am reading the code correctly, du=
ring crossover, if the
> >>>>>>>>> substrates are
> >>>>>>>>>> the same (i.=
e. all links have the same ID), which is
always the
> >>>>>>> case
> >>>>>>=
>>> in
> >>>>>>>>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either
=
> > parent1 or
> >>>>>>>>> parent2.
> >>>>>>>>>> Isn't it more normal when =
crossing over to take some from
> > parent1
> >>>>>>>>> and some
> >>>>>>>>=
>> from parent2? Why grab all from just one?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Thi=
s means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right?
It will
> >>>>>>>>> al=
ways grab
> >>>>>>>>>> the substrate of parent1 or the substrate of parent2=
.  If I
> > track
> >>>>>>>>> parent and
> >>>>>>>>>> offspring fitness, 10=
0% of the time the child has the exact
> > same
> >>>>>>>>> fitness as
> >>=
>>>>>>>> one of the two parents.
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> On to HyperNEAT=
:
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the r=
esulting
> > offspring.
> >>>>>>>>> The odd
> >>>>>>>>>> thing is that the =
organisms that are crossed only (i.e.
> > they are
> >>>>>>>>> never
> >>>>=
>>>>>> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their
parents
> >>>=
>>>>>> 98.88% of the
> >>>>>>>>>> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs =
out of 12257
that were
> >>>>>>>>> crossed over
> >>>>>>>>>> and not mutate=
d. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would
these
> >>>>>>> new
> >>>>>>>>> =
links
> >>>>>>>>>> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is beca=
use
> >>>>>>> nearly
> >>>>>>>>> every
> >>>>>>>>>> time that there is an e=
xtra link that gets placed in the
child,
> >>>>>>> the
> >>>>>>>>> parent
>=
 >>>>>>>>>> that donated that link is also the parent whose weights are
> >=
 being
> >>>>>>>>> grabbed,
> >>>>>>>>>> meaning that the crossover is only=
 copying the parent
> > (hence the
> >>>>>>>>> same
> >>>>>>>>>> fitness). =
It seems to me that crossover should be much more
> >>>>>>>>> disruptive, n=
o?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> As a final test, I did a set of=
 hyperneat and pneat runs
> > with the
> >>>>>>>>> default
> >>>>>>>>>> 'Mu=
tateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs
> >>>>>>> never
>=
 >>>>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experiment=
al treatments
> >>>>>>>>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the
> =
>>>>>>> MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>>>>>>> parameter was set to 1, so no or=
gs were crossed over.
> > Despite my
> >>>>>>>>> comments
> >>>>>>>>>> abov=
e, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross,
> > however
> >>>>>>>=
>> the
> >>>>>>>>>> difference was not tremendous (although it does seem to=
 be
> >>>>>>>>> statistically
> >>>>>>>>>> significant). For p-neat, the re=
verse was true. Nevertheless,
> >>>>>>> this
> >>>>>>>>> is not a
> >>>>>>>=
>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, because if
> >>>>>>>>=
> crossover does
> >>>>>>>>>> nothing most of the time, and I increase
Muta=
teOnlyProbability
> >>>>>>> from
> >>>>>>>>> .25 to
> >>>>>>>>>> 1, I have =
effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> >>>>>>> crossed
> >>>>>=
>>>> orgs are
> >>>>>>>>>> also mutated).
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Are th=
ese the intended consequences of crossover, or am I
> > missing
> >>>>>>>>>=
 something?
